Description: Fragment from a furnishing textile made in undyed linen, plain weave decorated with a band of tapestry (7.4x81.8cm) at the lower part and a square of tapestry (20.2x19cm) above, both surrounded by undyed linen loops (c.4cm long); the band of tapestry has medallions made of dark blue leaves and vegetal motifs, the centre is decorated by dark blue birds with red legs and beaks and rabbits with a red tongue and with different vegetal motifs (flowers, pomegranets); on the left there is a plain dark blue band indicating that one end of the decoration is preserved, there is also a simple selvedge preserved here; 8.5cm above the band is a square of tapestry, the centre of the square is decorated with a Greek cross in undyed linen, from which 4 vegetal branches spring, the end of each branch has 3 leaves which decorate the 4 angles of the central square; between the branches are 4 Greek vases; the central panel is framed with a freize of geometrical motifs made of undyed linen, flying-threads on a dark blue background; then again is framed with another band made of a medallion similar to the band beneath, but containing only vegetal and floral elements in dark blue on a beige background; the square is finally framed by a dark blue band; one simple selvedge is preserved o the left, where traces of holes can be seen indicating possible sewing; other edges are cut; plain weave: warp-bleached linen (S/22), weft-undyed line (S/15), supplementary weft-c.8mm apart, from which loops are made (c. 2.5cm out from the tapestry ornaments); tapestry on grouped threads: warp-bleached linen (S/8/grouped by 2-3), weft-bleached linen (S/62), dark blue wool (S/34), red wool (S); flying threads in yellow? wool and bleached linen (S)
Bibliographic references: Budge 1922 / British Museum. Guide to the fourth, fifth and sixth Egyptian rooms, and the Coptic room (p.227) (Table case H, no. 5)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Sir Ernest A T Wallis Budge
